title: JAIME BATEMAN CAYÓN. Comandante del M-19. Entrevista. 1982
creator: Luis Fernando Botero
description: Jaime Bateman Cayón, fue el fundador e inspirador de todo lo que se pueda saber del M-19.  Acá es entrevistado por Juan Guillermo Ríos, el periodista de TV estrella en los años 80s. En 1982, ganó las elecciones presidenciales el conservador Belisario Betancurt, especialmente por el triunfo en la costa caribe. Belisario convocó a las guerrillas, agrupadas en la "COORDINADORA GUERRILLERA SIMÓN BOLÍVAR", para unas negociaciones de paz. Hubo amnistía, especialmente para los integrantes del M-19 que estaban en las cárceles producto del fuerte "estado de sitio" del Gobierno de Turbay, y de estas negociaciones salió como producto final el partido de la Unión Patriótica.  En la entrevista, Bateman deja entrever que en Colombia la paz es difícil de conseguir en medio de las negociaciones, además hace una crítica a los medios de comunicación que "venden humo" según sea el presidente de turno. algo muy parecido a lo que está pasando hoy.. Éste es un tema actual, ya que el Gobierno Santos está dialogando con la guerrilla de las FARC en La Habana. comparen los contextos históricos, y saquen sus propias conclusiones.
subject: HISTORIA DE COLOMBIA

title: Roland – FARC-EP, el guerrillero que entregó el fusil y ahora preside los lisiados de la guerra
creator: Dick Emanuelsson
description:
Por Dick & Miriam Emanuelsson
Video: 

EL CONEJO-GUAJIRA / 170509 / Punto Transitorio de Normalización “Amaury Rodríguez” en Pondores, La Guajira / En este punto de concentración de guerrilleros de los frentes 19, 41 y 59, más el cordón de seguridad del comandante Iván Márquez, conversamos con el ex combatiente Roland. En julio de 2012 lo entrevistamos [https://youtu.be/WFEbcK2E5pw] sin saber que tres meses después saldría la noticia que decía que las Farc comenzaran un diálogo para llegar a un acuerdo de paz casi cinco años después.
Roland es uno de 500-1000 guerrilleros que han sido herido en el lago conflicto social y armado en Colombia y que han tenido que ver cuando una parte de su cuerpo ha sido mutilado por las bombas u otras armas. Pero se acabó la guerra para Roland y sus compañeros y compañeras y esta ansioso de iniciar una nueva vida.
Preside una nueva Fundación constituida por lisiados de guerra. Pero dice que no solo quiere limitar la nueva organización a los x combatientes de las Farc sino a sus viejos adversarios como paramilitares o incluso militares, aunque las FFMM tienen un excelente hospital en donde no ha ingresado ningún soldado herido o muerto en combate durante 2017.
Pero ¿como se siente Roland ante esa nueva situación, después 21 años en la montañas y selvas?
– La vida ha cambiado mucho ahora. Cero preocupaciones de persecuciones o bombardeo. Yo creo que igual que nosotros los integrantes del ejército pues también han cambiado porque no debe preocuparse que los vamos a buscar, que va haber enfrentamientos y hostigamientos. Yo creo que la paz ha beneficiado a todo el mundo, tanto guerrilleros como militares e incluso población civil. Pero, porque no decirlo, sectores económicos que nunca pudieron llegar a invertir en las áreas donde estuvimos nosotros por situaciones de la guerra.  Pero ahora me imagino que tienen toda vía libre para hacer esto. Ojala piensen en los recursos naturales y en las repercusiones en algunas cosas que tengan del país o el mismo planeta.
– La idea de éste tránsito es llegar a una paz estable y duradera, que no haya persecuciones más delante sino que esto realmente sea sincero y que sea un compromiso, no solamente entre la guerrilla y gobierno sino de todo el pueblo en general que al final es el mayor beneficiado con la terminación del conflicto.
‘El Hospital Militar es ahora un hospital de paz’, escribía Sandra Inés Henao, esposa del general Javier Flórez, integrante en la Comisión Técnica en las negociaciones de paz entre las Farc y el gobierno. En una carta publicada en el diario El Tiempo, celebra que no lleguen más heridos por la guerra:
“Si me hubieran dicho hace 3 años que en el Hospital Militar iban a dejar de llegar algún día heridos en combate, habría dicho: sí claro, claro. ¡Claro! Mi hospital militar era el hospital de la guerra, del dolor, de la lucha. ¡De los milagros! Donde traían a nuestros soldados en pedazos y reconstruían sus cuerpos con amor, magia, profesionalismo, inventando y aprendiendo cómo salvar cada vida que llegaba extinguiéndose. Cada semana, cuando salía de mi visita como dama protectora, le decía a mi familia: mañana no voy a poder levantarme y necesito urgentemente que por favorcito inventen un Dolex para el alma. Cada miércoles, mi corazón se sorprendía porque no podía creer que el ser humano pudiera regenerar su espíritu después de perder tantas partes de su cuerpo. ¡De su mente! Me maravillaba ver esas madres, esposas, familiares continuar cada día con tanto amor para sacar adelante, en una batalla magnánima, a sus seres amados. Era para mí increíble ver sonreír esos niños de 19, 20, 24 años, a veces sin cara, sin ojos, sin manos, sin dientes. ¡Sin piernas! Pero, ¡con una esperanza! Abracé tantos héroes mutilados, tantas familias. Abracé a los que recibían mis abrazos y luche hasta lograr abrazar a los que no querían recibirlos. Abracé a sus madres, padres, hermanos, hijos. Sin decir ni una palabra”.
“En 2016 recibimos solo 36 heridos en combate y en 2017, ninguno!
¡Ninguno!
¡Ninguno!
¡Dios mío! Lloré”.
Roland calcula que son 500-1000 lisiados ex combatientes con amputaciones en las Farc, de los 8.000 guerrilleros, incluyendo los combatientes encarcelados. Como el guerrillero en Combita, Boycá que tiene ambas manos amputadas y que esta ciego.

title: Raúl Benoit / La Matanza de Tacueyó,  1985. Archivos sin editar. Departamento del Cauca, Colombia.
creator: Raul Benoit
description:
LA VERDAD 

En esa época, año de 1985, había un grupo guerrillero llamado “Frente Ricardo Franco”, que decían ser disidentes de las FARC (Fuerzas Armadas Revolucionarias de Colombia), lo cual era negado por ellos. Años después, descubrió Raúl Benoit, que los hombres armados eran paramilitares o autodefensas al servicio de empresarios y la sociedad elitista. El jefe del “Frente Ricardo Franco”, era alías Javier Delgado, a quien lo vio Benoit, años después de la entrevista, entrar a un cuartel militar en Bogotá.    

"La Matanza de Tacueyó" fue uno de los más atroces crímenes de la violencia en Colombia. Mataron a más de 264 subversivos. Ocurrió en diciembre de 1985 en el Departamento del Cauca, hechos por estos paramilitares.   

Raúl Benoit revela todo el material, con las entrevistas y el video sin censura, para que usted juzgue.

Los autores fueron alias Javier Delgado (cuyo nombre real era José Fedor Rey) y Hernando Pizarro Leongómez, los dos asesinados en hechos oscuramente. Pizarro era hermano de Carlos Pizarro Leongómez, el comandante del M 19,  que no tenían conexión con él.

En el libro “Prohibido Decir Toda la Verdad”, Raúl Benoit narra esta historia. Lo puede encontrar en Amazon punto com.

title: Raúl Benoit / Cubrimiento periodístico, año 1985 / Guerrilla del M-19 al suroeste de Colombia.
creator: Raul Benoit
description:
El grupo guerrillero M-19 y el gobierno de turno, seguían intentando hacer la paz, pero, detrás habían organizaciones de la sociedad, incluyendo algunos militares del ejército, que se oponían para continuar la guerra y la matanza en Colombia, que se prolongaba desde hace décadas.

En los videos, aparecen los guerrilleros Carlos Pizarro Leongómez, uno de los comandantes, lo mismo que Carlos Chávez y Afranio Parra.


1) M-19 en la cordillera central los Robles, enero 20 de 1985.
2) Asalto a Toribio, abril 14 de 1985.
3) Denuncias campamentos urbanos del M 19, abril 20 de 1985.
4) Desmienten rumores sobre la división del M 19, abril 28 de 1985.
5) Rompimiento de la tregua por parte del M 19, junio 22 de 1985.
6) Enfrentamiento del ejército contra el M-19 a pesar de que intenta hacer la paz, julio 21 de 1985.
7) Violencia afecta la agroindustria del Valle del Cauca, agosto 3 de 1985.
8) Orden público. Muerte a Iván Marín Ospina, uno de los comandantes del M 19, agosto 31 de 1985.

title: COLOMBIA: COCA PLANTS & COCAINE
creator: AP Archive
description:
(30 Aug 2000) Spanish/Nat
U-S President Bill Clinton arrives in Colombia later today as he introduces Plan Colombia - the 1.3 (b) billion U-S aid package aimed at fighting narcotraffickers.
Under the plan, 60 combat helicopters will escort fumigation planes and ferry U-S trained anti-narcotics troops into drug producing plantations which cover vast areas of southern Colombia. 
But for thousands of farmers the plan is threatening the very thing they depend on to survive - coca, the plant that forms the base of cocaine.
The sun rises over the Caguan River, 280 miles (470 kilometres) from the Colombian capital, Bogota. 
Nestled alongside the river is the settlement of Penas Coloradas, a grimy settlement where coca is the economy's driving force and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) - the country's oldest and largest Marxist guerrilla group.
Farmers here grow coca.
This is FARC territory. The entire process, from the growing of coca to the creation and selling of the final product - cocaine - is monitored by rebels.
Their control here is strict. Liquor sales are forbidden between Monday and Friday. Theft and drunken behavious are punished.
It's in their interest to do so. The drugs help finance their 15-thousand strong force, fuelling a civil war which is fast approaching its fourth decade.
Now, the introduction of Plan Colombia is threatening the way of life of these farmers. They are far from grateful for the U-S backed intervention.
SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"With this Plan Colombia, if there is so much money to be distributed, why don't they give any of it to the poor? Why don't they give the poor money if there is so much money to give?" 
SUPER CAPTION: Laura, Coca farmer
FARC leaders claim the coming offensive will provide the FARC with an ample recruiting base among farmhands who could lose their livelihoods as a result.
SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"This is our life. This is our work. Here we all work together, look, behind us, this is how we all survive."
SUPER CAPTION: Fanny, Coca farmer
FARC rebels protect the crops of coca and poppy, from which heroin is made. 
They have vowed to fight the Plan.
As two Vietnam-era planes lazily circle these fields ready to dump a load or herbicides onto the plantation, the rebels open fire with their Galil assault rifles.
The crackle of automatic weapons fire splits the afternoon silence.
Plan Colombia will see a dramatic increase in anti-narcotics flights such as these, with more helicopters and planes being provided to the country.
But rather than back away in fear of the promised increase, FARC rebels have vowed to increase kidnappings - a longtime source of income for the group - in order to raise funds to equal the Plan.
Meanwhile, the growing and selling of coca continues.
In this simple shack by the side of the river farmers bring their cultivation of coca to be weighed, tested, and bought.
This coca paste - a semi processed form of cocaine - will be sold on to international markets - generating millions of dollars.
Coca farmers insist they have no choice.
SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"I have a family. What I earn goes to my mother, my wife. (Q) So it's from necessity. (A) Of course, it's from necessity, if I didn't have to I wouldn't do it."
SUPER CAPTION: Coca farmer
For the farmers in Penas Coloradas as in much of the rest of impoverished, rural Colombia, there are few viable alternatives to making a living than growing coca. 
They are skeptical of government pledges that the anti-drug offensive will be accompanied by loans and other assistance to help them grow legal crops.

title: Historia de un bombardeo
creator: Agencia Prensa Rural
description:
El sábado 18 de enero sobre las 11 de la noche Aviones de la Fuerza Aérea Bombardean un Campamento de las FARC-EP en la vereda La Siberia II Municipio de Tame en Arauca, a menos de 200 metros de una casa campesina.

Luego del bombardeo los helicópteros persiguieron por los potreros a los guerrilleros en desbandada, disparando municiones calibre .50 y matando varias reses y caballos de la finca.

El martes 21 de Enero Prensa Rural ingresó al lugar y recogió los testimonios de los campesinos, quienes, hasta ese momento, no podían recorrer su finca para buscar sus animales.

Una vez llegamos hasta el punto del bombardeo, unidades del Ejército Nacional nos impidieron el paso...

El teniente a cargo nos prohibió grabar y nos exigió borrar el material registrado...

Denunciamos la violación a la libre movilidad de los campesinos en su territorio,  bombardeos y ametrallamientos muy cerca de las casas así como la limitación a la libertad de prensa por unidades del ejercito nacional.

Reclamamos el respeto de los DDHH  y del DIH por parte de las fuerzas institucionales.

title: COLOMBIA: SIMITI: ATTACK ON POLICE STATION LEAVES 3 OFFICERS DEAD
creator: AP Archive
description:
(2 Jul 1997) Spanish/Nat

Three police officers have been killed in an attack on a police station in the isolated town of Simiti, 200 miles (322 kilometres) north of Colombia's capital, Bogota.

A police force of 20 officers fought off a rocket and mortar attack led by 300 armed guerrillas during an eleven-hour siege.

The guerrillas, believed to be members of the National Liberation Army (E-L-N), also attacked local residents and abducted two women, including a police officer's wife.

All but three of Simiti's 20-strong police force emerged alive from the wreckage of their bombed-out station on Tuesday morning.

The death toll in this rural outpost in the mountains north of Bogota, seemed low given the details of a siege which have since emerged.

More than 300 armed guerrillas of the Colombian rebel organisation, the National Liberation Army (E-L-N) attacked the station shortly after nightfall on Monday.

The police fought for their lives, with virtually no military assistance, as their station came under rocket and mortar fire.

A further 12 officers were injured.

The guerrillas also abducted two women, an officer's wife and the station's cook, before going on to attack a nearby bank and several public buildings.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"The truth is that, thanks to my men, we were prepared psychologically in every aspect of combat and ammunition. We went to war and we demonstrated what we were capable of because we were in the national police. We can fight, we are few, but we are tough."
SUPER CAPTION: Cesar Moreno, Simiti station commander

There were fears the siege would continue until all 20 police officers were dead and the town had been razed to the ground.

Military sources countered complaints that urgent calls for military assistance went unheeded, and said help was sent as soon as reports of the attack came in.

But counter-guerrilla forces only arrived in Simiti towards midday, Tuesday, to find scenes of devastation left in the guerrillas' wake.

Eye witnesses say the E-L-N troops had poured in on foot and in trucks.

The town's electricity supplies and telephone wires were cut off prior to the launch of the attack, shortly after nightfall.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"This is what happened. Bombs, bombs, exploding. I couldn't do anything. When a grenade arrived it went off in the kitchen, the table burst into little pieces. I went with my brothers to look for the children. I was with the young one that I had and I stayed by him."
SUPER CAPTION: Ester Munoz, witness to the attack

In the siege which followed, the survivors estimated more than five- thousand shots were fired, along with dynamite.

The purpose of the attack is not yet clear but it is just the latest clash in Colombia's on-going guerrilla war.

title: COLOMBIA: MILITARY SACKS NEARLY 400 OFFICERS
creator: AP Archive
description:
(17 Oct 2000) Spanish/Nat 

The Colombian military has sacked nearly 400 officers and soldiers in the biggest ever purge of the armed forces. 

It has denied this was in response to U-S pressure to improve their human rights records. 

The U-S government's 1.3 (b) billion U-S dollar contribution to Pastrana's Plan Colombia comes on the condition that progress be made on human rights violations. 

Military powers to dismiss soldiers for misconduct were granted by President Andres Pastrana in September. 

Many human rights groups say U-S money should not be going to the Colombian military because the army is alleged to maintain close ties with outlawed paramilitary death squads. 

Armed forces chief, General Fernando Tapias, said the dismissals were simply an effort to improve the efficiency of the 150 thousand-member forces. 

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"This is simply a discretional measure that seeks to strengthen the armed forces, seeks to strengthen their cohesion, to have absolute integrity and transparency throughout the armed forces and to give them a sense of professionalism."
SUPER CAPTION: General Fernando Tapias,  Armed Forces chief

The Colombian Defence Minister, Luis Fernando Ramirez has been evasive about why the 89 officers and the 299 rank-and-file members of the army, navy and air force had been dismissed but in a press conference he was adamant that the decision was not influenced by external factors.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"This has absolutely nothing to do with recommendations or suggestions from any foreign government. This is an absolutely autonomous decision. Absolutely nobody knows the officers and soldiers listed at the moment, only the armed forces and the government know. Other Colombian organisations will know later but it doesn't respond to any suggestion or solicitation from any foreign government or any other organisation. It is an eminently autonomous decision. As General Tapias said, what we want to achieve by this decision, which is historic and which has never been taken before in the armed forces, is that from here emerges a much more solid, professional and modern armed forces."
SUPER CAPTION: Luis Fernando Ramirez, Colombian Defence Minister

Pastrana's U-S backed Plan Colombia is unpopular with Colombians and international groups alike.

Plan Colombia is an initiative aimed at wiping out drug trafficking from Colombia and strengthening its democracy. 

Activists and local Colombian officials object to the program, saying it focuses too much on the military aspect and will intensify the civil war.

They criticise the government for agreeing to U-S suggestions in order to receive their financial help at the expense of the true needs of local people.

title: COLUMBIA: REBELS CLAIM CONTROL OF CHOACHI VILLAGE
creator: AP Archive
description:
(28 May 1995) Spanish/Nat

Colombian rebels on Saturday claimed control of a town just 45 kilometers from the capital Bogota.

These are rebels from the Colombian Revolutionary Armed Forces, or FARC, who had just taken the village of Choachi, only 45 kilometers from the capital, Bogota.

The action is part of a rebel offensive aimed at pressing the government into starting negotiations with the guerrilla movement.

Even though Choachi is very close to Bogota, the rebels had plenty of time to celebrate their victory having a few beers and holding a press conference with reporters from the capital.

A rebel leader offered his conditions to begin the dialogue with the government.

SOUNDBITE: What the government should do is stop their offensive against us. That is the only way we will start talking with them."
SUPER CAPTION: FARC Rebel Leader

The attack is part of several skirmishes by the rebels around the capital, a show of force that is convincing many Colombians that the rebel movements are a force to reckon with.

Thousands of people have died in Colombia in the last three decades since leftist guerrilla groups started their armed struggle against the government.

title: COLOMBIA:  FIERCE CLASHES AFTERMATH
creator: AP Archive
description:
(13 Jul 1999) Spanish/Nat 

Fierce clashes between the Colombian army and the FARC guerrillas largely subsided on Monday, with both sides claiming victory.

Since fighting began on Thursday, at least 59 police and soldiers have been killed and the army says it killed more than 200 guerrillas.

Earlier on Monday, in a show of war propaganda, reporters were flown to one of the worst hit areas, where the Commander of the Colombian Army proudly displayed the corpses of some 30 FARC guerrillas.

Trying to convince a skeptical media, troops brought journalists to an army base where they displayed the bodies of 30 guerrillas.

They were allegedly killed in Puerto Lleras, a town 114 miles (190 kilometers) from Colombia's capital Bogota. 

Young women made up about a third of the dead on display at the army base in Granada, twenty minutes by helicopter from Puerto Lleras.

Many still had red, yellow and blue banners across the chests - national colours Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) fighters often wear into battle.

Military leaders are saying they saved the country from one of the guerrillas' most ambitious offensives since taking up arms in the 1960s.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"The Colombian Army will never allow these bandits to take power by force. It's impossible for the FARC. They must realise they will never get it".
SUPERCAPTION: General Jorge Mora, commander of the Colombian army

Many observers have their doubts. 

They feel the FARC is making steady progress - even if it lost some fighters, didn't permanently seize territory or inflict heavy government casualties in its latest offensive.

The rebels launched their offensive less than two weeks before a planned round of negotiations with the government of President Andres Pastrana to end Colombia's 35-year conflict.

The FARC is demanding sweeping reforms to attack poverty, redistribute land and clean up political corruption.

Fighting raged over the weekend in 10 of the country's 32 provinces, killing at least 59 police and soldiers as well as two children whose house was destroyed by a rebel bomb.

The army claims it killed a fifth of an estimated one-thousand rebel fighters participating in the attacks.

Puerto Lleras, a small river port in the jungles of eastern Meta province, was the scene of some of the worst clashes over the weekend.

FARC fighters stormed into the town on Saturday night and pounded the local police station with rockets and homemade missiles.

The entire village of Puerto Lleras has been looted or destroyed.

Most of the villagers, as this old woman, are left with nothing else than their despair.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"I don't really know know what to say. I don't understand why they did it. They left us in complete ruin".
SUPERCAPTION: Villager

In the town itself, army explosives experts worked to defuse homemade missiles left by the guerrillas, who flattened a police station and homes with the crude, but deadly weapons fashioned from gas canisters.

Despite the latest claims by the Colombian army, the 15-thousand member FARC has enjoyed a nearly unbroken string of victories during the past three years.

In a much larger offensive last August, the rebels killed 143 soldiers and police, took more than hundred captive and overran a major anti-narcotics base.

title: COLOMBIA: BOGOTA: CAR BOMB EXPLODES IN BUSY STREET
creator: AP Archive
description:
(11 Nov 1999) Spanish/Nat 

A powerful car bomb has exploded in a busy street in an upmarket part of the Colombian capital, Bogota, killing six people and injuring at least twelve others. 

The bomb, apparently placed in a green Renault car, destroyed a house and a restaurant and blew out the windows of banks, hotels and seven-storey apartment buildings 50 metres across the street.

No armed group has claimed responsibility for the bombing so far, although there is growing speculation that drug-traffickers are behind the attack. 

For the second time this week, a car bomb has exploded in the Colombian capital, Bogota.

The powerful bomb ripped through a residential area in the north of the city, killing six people and injuring at least 12 others. 

The bomb, apparently containing ten kilogrammes of dynamite, left a one-metre-deep crater in the street.  

There was also extensive damage to nearby houses and cars.

One of the wounded described what happened.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"There was an explosion. I don't know what happened and when I opened the door the whole thing blew up. We don't know anything more than that. It looks like the bomb was just over there. I have been injured but I can't leave my house because they will loot it." 
SUPER CAPTION: Francisco, Car bomb victim

The mayor of Bogota said the bomb could be a response to a government move against drug traffickers. 

Colombia has again decided to start extraditing alleged drug traffickers to the United States.

The Supreme Court ruled this week that the extradition of two alleged drug-traffickers, a Colombian and a Venezuelan, could take place.

It's now up to the government of President Andres Pastrana to give the go-ahead. 

The Colombian authorities have offered a 50-thousand U-S dollar reward to anybody offering information that could lead to the arrest of the perpetrators.

title: COLOMBIA: PACHO: COMMUNE
creator: AP Archive
description:
(2 Nov 2000) Spanish/Nat 
XFA
Almost four months ago, a young Irish boy who grew up in a commune in Colombia was  killed by Colombia's largest rebel group, the Armed Revolutionary Forces of Colombia,  or FARC. 

His grandmother, Jenny James, was a pacifist who founded the commune on which he  lived 11 years ago. 

Now, James says that she is seeking justice for her grandson and she wants to see  that his death is avenged. 

This farm seems like a piece of paradise. 

Tucked away in the countryside about 50 kilometres away from Colombia's capital  Bogota, the people here live at one with nature. 

The girls go and plant and harvest vegetables every day. 

They eat mainly what they grow. 

The commune has dwindled to about a dozen people - but the group has been in  Colombia for about 11 years, living in different areas of the country. 

Jenny James left her native England, went to Ireland, and founded the commune in  Colombia after wandering through Latin America. 

As a devoted ecologist and anti-nuclear activist she wanted to be as far away from the  city as possible. 

But the commune began to have difficulties several months ago when members were  thrown off the land they were living by a local FARC commander. 

They then moved to the place where they are now. 

James' grandson, 18-year-old Tristan, and another Colombian friend returned to the  village on July 9 to see his half-brother who had been left behind with a local family. 

That was when the problems began. 

SOUNDBITE: (English) 
" The leaders of the gang got themselves very drunk, and as soon as they saw our boys  returning from their visit to my grandson, they came at them, they chased them, into  the middle of a football match, everyone ran away screaming, didn't help our boys, as  far as we know our boys were captured and they had their hands tied behind their  backs, and they were taken to a room and we don't know what happened in that room,  and then they were taken out further down the road, and as far as we know our  grandson was crying, and they slit his throat." 
SUPERCAPTION: Jenny James, grandmother of murdered boy 

Tristan's friend was also decapitated and both their bodies were doused with gasoline  and burned. 

Tristan was an actor in local troupes which put on performances about ecological  themes. 

Like most of the children here, he had never had any formal education. 

He was just about to return to Ireland to 'discover his roots' when the tragedy happened.  
James squarely blames the FARC for his death. 

SOUNDBITE: (English) 
" We are doing what we can but at the moment the latest block that we've met is that  the local commander who was the one who chucked us out, who is as far as we are  concerned a very non-political and very violent and very stupid man, and who more or  less caused these deaths and even ordered them, he has now become the head of the  25 Front of the FARC. Which organises the area where all this occured, and to go there  at the moment would be to invite total tragedy for all of us. 
SUPERCAPTION:Jenny James, grandmother of murdered boy 

James's political leaning's would have previously lead her to support a peasant based  rebel movement like the FARC. 

She initially had wanted to take the commune to Bolivia because that was were Che  Guevara had died. 

But now she says that she considers the FARC murderers and wants to use her  grandson's death to publicise what is happening here. 


James's daughter and another member of the commune wrote this song to  commemorate the two young men's deaths.

title: COLOMBIA: FARC REBELS CLASH WITH GOVERNMENT TROOPS
creator: AP Archive
description:
(21 Jun 1998) Spanish/Nat

Marxist rebels fought pitched battles with government troops on Saturday on a highway east of the capital, with reports that they set fire to more than 20 vehicles.

The fighting lasted all day and spilled into Sunday as the troubled, volatile country went to the polls in the Presidential elections.

Motorists caught in the crossfire were forced to abandon their cars and run for cover.

The latest fighting broke out about 70 kilometers (44 miles) east of the Colombian capital, Bogota, on the main highway near Villavicencio.

FARC (Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia) guerillas opened fire.

Government soldiers answered with a hail of bullets triggering a fierce gun battle.

The fighting lasted all day, Saturday, with reports that one soldier was wounded.

Sporadic clashes flared up through much of Sunday, despite government efforts to ensure a peaceful day at the polls by deploying 200-thousand troops.

The FARC is reportedly trying to discourage voters from going to the polls.

The armed group had called for a transportation strike, and then on Saturday blocked off this road.

Motorists along the busy highway were caught unawares - trapped in the middle of a raging gun battle.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"What can I do?  I have no choice.  I just have to try to keep on driving through."
SUPER CAPTION: Vox Pop, Truck Driver

Caught in the crossfire, there was nothing these people could do except dive for cover - their vehicles were their only shields from stray bullets.

The FARC has been waging a war of attrition against the Colombian state for more than three decades.

During the tenure of outgoing president Ernesto Samper violence from both leftist guerrillas and extreme-right paramilitaries worsened.

title: COLOMBIA: BARRANCABERMEJA: PROTESTS CONTINUE AFTER MASSACRE
creator: AP Archive
description:
(7 Jun 1998) Spanish/Nat

Protests continued in Barrancabermeja, Colombia, on Saturday following news of a  mass slaughter in which 25 men and women died. 

The victims had been executed by a paramilitary group for alleged rebel activity though  human rights activists say army and police units were also involved.

A rebel spokesman has vowed to avenge their deaths. 

The 25 coffins by a roadside in this oil refining city north of Bogota are dedicated to the  latest victims of Colombian violence.

A sad reminder that Barrancabermeja, home to 240-thousand, is trapped in the bloody  crossfire.

The dead disappeared last month and were later executed by a right-wing paramilitary  group - the so-called United Self-Defence Group of Colombia (A-U-C).

Human rights activists say that army and police units abetted the kidnapping. 

Witnesses claim security forces were at the scene of the assault
moments before 50 masked gunmen entered a poor neighborhood, killed seven people  and carted away 25 others in trucks.

But local army and police chiefs have denied involvement in the crime. 

Investigations are underway but the families of the dead remain in shock.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"My sons were never those kinds of people. We are humble, hardworking people. We  are not bad people like these types. My son was never any kind of rebel. That was  never the case, you couldn't say that." 
Q: "The paramilitaries say they killed them because they were involved with the  guerrillas."
A: "No sir. That is a false lie." 
SUPER CAPTION: Alfonso, father of one of the dead 

Maria, wife of one of the dead, still hopes for news that her husband is alive. 

But the paramilitary group responsible for his capture confirmed on Thursday that all 25  had been first tried and later executed.

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"A young man who only dedicated himself to his work, his home. He didn't have any  problems with anybody. They took him and until now, nobody knows anything. So we  want to ask if they are still holding them alive that they return them to us, that they (the  prisoners) take heart because their captors also have families and they know what it is  like to lose somebody close to you. And if they are dead, that they hand them (the  bodies) over. What can we do? They have to hand them over, alive or dead, please hand  them over."
SUPER CAPTION: Maria, wife of one of the dead

The dead were accused of working closely with the E-L-N (National Liberation Army)  and E-P-L (Popular Liberation Army).

A spokesman for the E-L-N denied this was the case. 

But he also vowed the paramilitaries and any associated groups would pay for this  mistake. 

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
"We make it very clear that all these commanders are military targets. The fundamental  idea is to exercise a revolutionary justice over them and we will apply it with all the  rigour that our abilities allow - those guilty of this massacre. And we have to say to  them that they got it wrong. We must tell Ernesto Samper's government, the defence  minister, and the chief of armed forces that they all got it wrong, that they have not  assassinated any rebel member of the E-L-N or the E-P-L. They were civilians. They will  have to pay for their deaths. And most certainly they will be made to pay."
SUPER CAPTION: Rafael, E-L-N Commander 

His declaration prolongs the likelihood of continued war within and around  Barrancabermeja.

This, despite a three week civil protest for peace which culminated in strike action. 

SOUNDBITE: (Spanish) 
SUPER CAPTION: Rafael, E-L-N Commander

title: COLOMBIA: PRESIDENT SAMPER ORDERS OFFENSIVE AGAINST REBELS
creator: AP Archive
description:
(1 Jun 1995) STORY
Spanish/Nat
Colombian president Ernesto Samper has ordered a full-scale offensive against rebel forces locked in combat with his government.
Over the past four days rebels have launched a violent campaign in which more than 40 people have been killed.
The heating up of the three-decade long conflict is making peace negotiations look increasingly shaky.
APTV was with a corps of elite soldiers when they dealt a major blow against the guerrillas by seizing a camp belonging to the powerful Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia.
These four suspected guerrillas were captured by the army when they raided a large guerrilla camp hidden in the mountainous and thickly forested department of Boyaca, north of the capital Bogota.
Four suspected guerrillas and one soldiers were killed in a fierce firefight when the army attacked this camp belonging to the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC.
According to the Colombian military, it is the second largest rebel camp taken by the army.
Seventeen tons of supplies were seized from the camp, among them quantities of propaganda material.
SOUNDBITE: (Spanish)
"This is an important blow on behalf of the country. What we're doing is maintaining the stability of the country and that's important. This a very important part of the country. It's an oil producing area. It's the heart of the country's economy. So this a blow the army has dealt for the country."
SUPER CAPTION: Major Reyes
The Cuban-inspired FARC is the oldest and largest of Colombia's guerrilla groups. For three decades it has been locked in combat with successive governments.
It and the Maoist National Liberation Army are engaged in preliminary peace talks with the government.
In an upsurge of guerrilla violence, police and army patrols have been ambushed and, increasingly, the rebels have launched attacks from the large slums surrounding the capital.
Yesterday (Wednesday) three policemen were killed and two others injured in a guerrilla attack in the middle class Bogota suburb of Kennedy.
The army is now concentrating its resources on the mountainous area to the north and east of the capital where FARC forces have recently launched several ambushes on the security forces.

title: Fusiles de madera (2002).
creator: Archivo Revolucionario
description:
El siguiente documental fue realizado por Carlos Cardenas y Carlos Duarte como parte del material investigatorio para obtener el titulo de antropólogos.


Este documental aborda desde una investigación de tipo etnográfica un campamento del ELN (Ejercito de liberación nacional) en especial en lo denominado escuela de combatientes, donde en la organización guerrillera se conjuga el ejercicio teórico tanto el práctico para dotar a los nuevos combatientes de nociones básicas politico-militares para su nueva vida al interior del movimiento guerrillero.


Para la profundización en el tema del ejército de liberación nacional recomendamos el siguiente material bibliográfico.


-ELN 47 años de historia.
http://www.cedema.org/uploads/ELN_47.pdf


-Las guerras de la paz.
https://drive.google.com/file/d/1U-0hPnslvJXjPV5ZXlEKMVHEE74lPhpp/view?fbclid=IwAR0iJ8o6GEDf6bK2TmfIqXn9tJL-N_endE49fnNUm4uBl20QS6DdnBAyX2I


-Camilistas vigencia de una tradiccion revolucionaria de nuetsra amercia.
http://www.cedema.org/uploads/camilistas.pdf
